Tropospheric Air Quality Working Group Report

Working Group Report

Ken Pickering (NASA GSFC) Annmarie Eldering (JPL) Bryan Duncan (NASA GSFC)

Current Aura Air Quality Activities
Current Aura Air Quality Activities

• Fishman: OMI – NCEP/GFS SCO; Texas case studies • Yang: OMI – MLS with PV mapping • Pickering: OMI – MLS (Ziemke) vs. Eta/CMAQ • Chatfield: South-Central Calif. Air Quality analysis • Kurosu: OMI HCHO and CHO-CHO • Levelt: European air quality modeling and assimilations systems • Bowman: Use of TES O3 and CO in Texas AQS

Air pollution often travels above boundary layer & impacts surface via subsidence and/or fumigation.

layer & impacts surface via subsidence
and/or fumigation.

Data Product Intercomparison Issues
Data Product Intercomparison Issues

• Talks by Fishman, Yang, & Pickering raised issue: How do we compare Aura tropospheric ozone products using residual methods?
• Talks by Fishman, Yang, & Pickering raised issue: How
do we compare Aura tropospheric ozone products using
residual methods?

 Difficulties arise due to various tropopause definitions. Therefore, standard definition is required. But which one? Compute TCO > 500 mb instead?

How well represented is convection in regional/global models?
How well represented is convection
in regional/global models?

• Boundary layer venting by convection is a critical process for air quality and long- range transport.

critical process for air quality and long-

Vertical Composition Information
Vertical Composition Information

• Vertical profile information is critical for assessing transport & air quality (e.g., above boundary layer versus near-surface composition and transport).
• Vertical profile information is critical for
assessing transport & air quality (e.g.,
above boundary layer versus near-surface
composition and transport).

• Necessary to understand long-range transport versus in situ production of pollution.
• Necessary to understand long-range
transport versus in situ production of t r a n s p o r t

i n
s i t u p r o d u c t i o n
o f
pollution.

The Future
The Future

• The working group only touched the surface of all of the issues related to use of Aura data for air quality. We needed more time.
